verses.text: At that time, Jesus was passing through the grainfields on the Sabbath. His disciples were hungry and began to pick heads of grain and eat them.
verses.comment: The disciples' actions followed the law on gleaning (Deut. 23:25). The setting highlights conflict over proper Sabbath observance.

verses.text: But when the Pharisees saw this, they said to him, 'Look, your disciples are doing what is not lawful to do on the Sabbath.'
verses.comment: The Pharisees saw the picking as work forbidden on the Sabbath, expressing the strictness of their interpretation.

verses.text: He said to them, 'Have you not read what David did when he was hungry, he and those who were with him?
verses.comment: Jesus references 1 Samuel 21 to justify mercy over ritual, linking himself to David's authority and foreshadowing his greater claim.

verses.text: How he entered the house of God and they ate the bread of the Presence, which it was not lawful for him nor for those with him to eat, but only for the priests?
verses.comment: David acted on necessity in the holy place, foreshadowing Christ's authority over the Temple and its Law.

verses.text: Or have you not read in the law how on the Sabbath the priests in the temple break the Sabbath and are considered blameless?
verses.comment: Jesus points to lawful Sabbath work of priests, suggesting a higher principle than strict Sabbath rule.

verses.text: I tell you, something greater than the temple is here.
verses.comment: Christ claims a divinely superior authority over the Temple itself—a clear statement of his divinity and messianic fulfillment.

verses.text: If you had known what this means, 'I desire mercy and not sacrifice,' you would not have condemned the innocent.
verses.comment: Quoting Hosea, Jesus calls for a merciful spirit over external ritual, teaching a spiritual interpretation beyond mere law observance.

verses.text: For the Son of Man is Lord of the Sabbath.
verses.comment: Jesus explicitly claims divine authority, evoking 'Son of Man' from Daniel—a title pointing to messianic power.

verses.text: He left that place and went into their synagogue.
verses.comment: Jesus continues teaching, undeterred by religious opposition.

verses.text: And a man was there whose hand was withered. And they asked him, 'Is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath?' So that they might accuse him.
verses.comment: A test to trap Jesus in violating the Sabbath, showing their concern for legalism over compassion.

verses.text: He said to them, 'If any of you has a sheep and it falls into a pit on the Sabbath, will you not take hold of it and lift it out?
verses.comment: Draws on Old Testament concern for mercy and practical need, teaching that true law includes compassion.

verses.text: How much more valuable is a man than a sheep! Therefore, it is lawful to do good on the Sabbath.
verses.comment: Jesus prioritizes human welfare over strict rulekeeping, embodying both literal and spiritual fulfillment of the law.

verses.text: Then he said to the man, 'Stretch out your hand.' And he stretched it out, and it was restored, whole like the other.
verses.comment: Jesus miraculously heals, demonstrating his authority and confirming his identity as Messiah (see Isa. 35:6).

verses.text: But the Pharisees went out and immediately began plotting against him, how they might destroy him.
verses.comment: The growing hostility shows resistance to Christ’s divinity and mission.

verses.text: Aware of this, Jesus withdrew from there. Many followed him, and he healed them all.
verses.comment: Jesus’ merciful power continues, compassion not limited by opposition.

verses.text: And he warned them not to make him known.
verses.comment: Jesus instructs secrecy to avoid premature conflict and fulfill prophecy (see Isa. 42:1–4).

verses.text: This was to fulfill what was spoken through the prophet Isaiah:
verses.comment: Matthew points to fulfillment of messianic prophecy, showing Christ as the awaited Servant.

verses.text: 'Behold, my Servant whom I have chosen, my beloved in whom my soul delights. I will put my Spirit upon him, and he will proclaim justice to the nations.'
verses.comment: Allusion to Jesus' baptism, where the Spirit comes upon him. Points to his divinely anointed mission.

verses.text: 'He will not quarrel or cry out, nor will anyone hear his voice in the streets.'
verses.comment: The messiah will be gentle and humble, fulfilling Isaiah’s vision of a peaceful servant.

verses.text: 'A bruised reed he will not break, and a smoldering wick he will not snuff out, until he brings justice to victory.'
verses.comment: Christ cares for the weak and faithful, bringing healing and restoration—a spiritual interpretation of his mission.

verses.text: 'And in his name the nations will put their hope.'
verses.comment: The messianic promise extends beyond Israel, anticipating the Church’s global reach in his name.

verses.text: Then a demon-possessed man who was blind and mute was brought to Jesus, and he healed him, so that the man could both speak and see.
verses.comment: Christ demonstrates his divine power over evil, fulfilling Old Testament prophecy of Messiah’s healing ministry.

verses.text: And all the crowds were amazed and said, 'Could this be the Son of David?'
verses.comment: Recognition of Jesus as messianic king links directly to the Davidic promise and high christology.

verses.text: But when the Pharisees heard this, they said, 'It is only by Beelzebul, the prince of demons, that this man casts out demons.'
verses.comment: Opponents ascribe Jesus’ power to evil, denying his divinity and fulfillment of prophecy.

verses.text: Knowing their thoughts, Jesus said to them, 'Every kingdom divided against itself is brought to ruin, and no city or house divided against itself will stand.'
verses.comment: Jesus demonstrates supernatural knowledge, another sign of divinity, and gives a logical defense.

verses.text: If Satan is casting out Satan, he is divided against himself. How then will his kingdom stand?
verses.comment: Refutes the Pharisees’ accusation through reason, highlighting the absurdity of their claim.

verses.text: And if I cast out demons by Beelzebul, by whom do your sons cast them out? Therefore, they will be your judges.
verses.comment: Jesus turns their accusation against them, exposing their spiritual inconsistency.

verses.text: But if I cast out demons by the Spirit of God, then the kingdom of God has come upon you.
verses.comment: Jesus claims authoritative Spirit empowerment, directly announcing the coming of God's Kingdom—a major christological claim.

verses.text: Or how can someone enter a strong man's house and plunder his goods, unless he first ties up the strong man? Then he may plunder his house.
verses.comment: Implied reference to Jesus’ victory over Satan, spiritually fulfilling Isaiah’s prophecy.

verses.text: Whoever is not with me is against me, and whoever does not gather with me scatters.
verses.comment: Jesus calls for a total commitment to himself, foreshadowing the need for visible unity in the Church.

verses.text: Therefore I say to you, every sin and blasphemy will be forgiven people, but blasphemy against the Spirit will not be forgiven.
verses.comment: Warning about rejecting God's Spirit, traditionally seen as final impenitence—a sobering spiritual lesson.

verses.text: And whoever speaks a word against the Son of Man will be forgiven, but whoever speaks against the Holy Spirit will not be forgiven, either in this age or in the age to come.
verses.comment: Implicit mention of an ‘age to come’ suggests ongoing post-mortem consequences; hints at a spiritual reality beyond this life.

verses.text: 'Either make the tree good and its fruit good, or make the tree bad and its fruit bad, for the tree is known by its fruit.'
verses.comment: Consistent biblical theme: inner character determines outward actions; literal and spiritual interpretations apply.

verses.text: 'You brood of vipers, how can you speak good when you are evil? For out of the abundance of the heart the mouth speaks.'
verses.comment: Strong prophetic language reminiscent of John the Baptist; shows the connection between heart and words.

verses.text: 'The good person out of his good treasure brings forth good, and the evil person out of his evil treasure brings forth evil.'
verses.comment: The spiritual fruit is rooted in a renewed heart; strong call for inward transformation.

verses.text: 'I tell you, on the day of judgment people will give account for every careless word they speak.'
verses.comment: Affirms a final judgment and the importance of even words in moral accountability.

verses.text: 'For by your words you will be justified, and by your words you will be condemned.'
verses.comment: Links justification and condemnation not only to faith but also to spoken deeds. The context hints at the value of both faith and works for salvation.

verses.text: Then some of the scribes and Pharisees answered, 'Teacher, we want to see a sign from you.'
verses.comment: Their request reflects unbelief rather than true faith, seeking proof rather than trusting spiritual authority.

verses.text: He answered them, 'An evil and adulterous generation seeks for a sign, but no sign will be given except the sign of the prophet Jonah.'
verses.comment: Jesus points to Jonah’s experience as a foreshadowing of his own death and resurrection—a high christological claim.

verses.text: 'For just as Jonah was three days and three nights in the belly of the great fish, so will the Son of Man be three days and three nights in the heart of the earth.'
verses.comment: Explicit prophecy of Christ’s death, burial, and resurrection—a central event in salvation history.

verses.text: 'The men of Nineveh will rise up at the judgment with this generation and condemn it, for they repented at the preaching of Jonah, and behold, something greater than Jonah is here.'
verses.comment: Jesus claims superiority to Jonah, interpreting his mission as the fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy.

verses.text: 'The queen of the South will rise up at the judgment with this generation and condemn it, for she came from the ends of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon, and behold, something greater than Solomon is here.'
verses.comment: Christ presents himself as the fulfillment and surpassing of both prophet and king—a deep christological message.

verses.text: 'When an unclean spirit goes out of a person, it passes through waterless places seeking rest, but finds none.'
verses.comment: Teaches a spiritual reality about spiritual warfare and the need for ongoing spiritual vigilance.

verses.text: 'Then it says, ‘I will return to my house from which I came.’ And when it comes, it finds the house empty, swept, and in order.'
verses.comment: Spiritual preparation and transformation must be genuine and persistent, otherwise evil returns.

verses.text: 'Then it goes and brings along seven other spirits more evil than itself, and they enter and live there. And the last state of that person is worse than the first. So it will be also with this evil generation.'
verses.comment: Warns of the dangers of incomplete conversion, and the need for true spiritual protection and enduring faith.

verses.text: While he was still speaking to the crowds, his mother and brothers stood outside, seeking to speak with him.
verses.comment: Reference to Jesus’ family highlights both biological and spiritual relationships.

verses.text: Someone said to him, 'Look, your mother and your brothers are standing outside, wishing to speak with you.'
verses.comment: Reminds us of the place of Jesus’ family, and prepares for a teaching on spiritual kinship.

verses.text: But he replied to the person who told him, 'Who is my mother, and who are my brothers?'
verses.comment: Jesus redirects attention from natural family to spiritual family—those united with him in faith and obedience.

verses.text: And stretching out his hand toward his disciples, he said, 'Here are my mother and my brothers.'
verses.comment: Jesus points to the deeper spiritual family, emphasizing unity within the body of believers—a foundational Church teaching.

verses.text: For whoever does the will of my Father in heaven, he is my brother and sister and mother.
verses.comment: Participation in God's family is rooted in obeying the Father’s will; this implicitly calls for unity, submission, and life in the visible Church Jesus builds.
